Coloradans want to take the long view and invest in our state‚Äôs future. To do this, we cannot neglect our schools. As a first step, we must find some way to prune the fiscal underbrush that threatens so deeply our investments in the future. Our children deserve better.

Shrinking state budgets have increased class sizes, reduced vital support for students like mental health services & special education, and sometimes slashed school weeks to 4 days. We cannot allow mindless budget shortfalls to force wrongheaded changes to our kids' education.

A few important stats: Colorado teachers are now earning less than they did 15 years ago, when compared to inflation. The gap between what a college graduate makes as a teacher and what she could make in another profession in our state is the largest in the country.

full_text: We stand with @DenverPost journalists‚Äì& journalists around our state/country‚Äìwho are doing everything in their power to salvage newsrooms while continuing to inform communities. Thanks for all of your hard work to defend free press, use edited content & preserve our civic future.

As the Editorial Board points out: ‚ÄúReduction in quality leads to a reduction of trust.‚Äù In a hyper-partisan &‚Äúfake news‚Äù oriented world, a lack of trust in local papers is the last thing our society needs. A free & vigilant press is essential to our function as a democracy.

Now the Rocky Mountain News is gone, and today over two dozen employees at @DenverPost are being shown the door (after years of other major cuts). This editorial is worth a read, because, as the headline indicates, we must save the Denver Post: https://t.co/67aV0hodXE
